author: stephania
title: Project Monarch - GoingUP
description: We are solving problems linked to pseudonymous identity, facilitating collaboration & improving accountability and trustworthiness in web3.

f6_assessments.q0:
On paper, this seems like it might match the challenge brief ("people who used to work on ethereum want to do a project on Cardano", is the way I'm reading it).  I can't quite agree that this is a good fit for the brief, but I'm willing to give a half-star for the benefit of the doubt.

Proposer would improve this score with me by addressing the "Migration" element of the challenge category's brief more clearly.
f6_assessments.q1: Two of the proposers have broad experience, the third somewhat less. The details of the plan for actually building the thing are somewhat vague, which is the way one would expect for a commercial venture as this appears to be. Accordingly, it's hard to distinguish between "likely" and "highly likely".
f6_assessments.q2: The metrics mentioned for the project sound quite reasonable for checking up on progress and evaluating whether the funds will have been used to good effect.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal outlines GoingUP, a platform to build professional reputation and network. There isn't much detail on the features in the proposal, but a look through additional documents gives us good information: "GoingUP is professional networking platform for creators and builders in web3. We enable you to easily discover, connect, collaborate with diverse professionals in the space and we help you tract your interactions to build your reputation on-chain." There are also designs and a feature list available: a portfolio of past projects, discovery of DAOs, contributors, new projects, on chain reputation, badges and tokens. 

The product the team wants to build solves a critical problem in decentralized coordination. It allows DAOs and decentralized communities to get work done, find new work and network. I believe it to be a worthwhile problem to solve. I don't believe it aligns well with the challenge however. The challenge's is about migrating users and developers from Ethereum to Cardano. The proposal does not mention how this project would accomplish that. 

The proposal does state integration with Milkomeda and Cardano yet the website doesn't mention either. The MVP video shows Metamask integration working so we know the product is chain agnostic (it works with Ethereum and Cardano). That might help with challenge goals if there were some incentive built in to migrate users from EVM based chains to Cardano but no such thing is mentioned.

This proposal would be a better fit for DApps and Integrations challenge. As it stands, I don't see any alignment of the proposal with Ethereum Migration. It's a shame because I think this has great potential.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal doesn't provide details on the features of the product. There is some information available on the website but it is more about the intention rather than specifics. There is a roadmap available on the proposal and on the website. The roadmap on the website marks mid March 2022 as an MVP launch and white paper release. Neither were available on their website, Discord or Twitter as of 22nd of March 2022. A short MVP video was made available after I asked on Discord (thank you proposers for the quick response). It only showed a Metamask integration (not a Cardano wallet) and basic website functionality. So nothing much to go on at this point.

The budget is lacking details. 75K has been set aside for developer work. How many engineers, what skills are necessary is not known. 15K is set aside for user base building. The remaining 35K USD is unaccounted for. The proposers don't mention how they will use this amount at all.

The team is made up of 3 people. It is an experienced, capable team bringing together business, design and technical backgrounds. But only one is a software developer and this is a highly technical project. It is a product with smart contract integrations that are non trivial. The software developer has experience in Solidity smart contracts but  The proposers will need extra support in building the product. They don't mention this as a challenge or give any plans as to how they'll implement their solution.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal doesn't provide clear deliverables. The roadmap is a guide towards what we can expect when but it's lacking specifics. We expect an Alpha Mid March and a Beta in April. What will be the difference we don't know. There will be "Full integrations with sidechains Milkomeda & Cardano" in May. What does that mean? Does that mean we can take payments in ADA? Does it mean we have NFTs as badges on Cardano? It's not clear. Nearly all targets in the roadmap are unclear in this way. In July we expect "Creation of a new professional identity and reputation standard.". In September: "Development of on-chain professional identity infrastructure and smart contracts.". What these mean are unclear to me as a software developer. The lack of details on features and roadmap make it difficult to audit this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The project tries to create a platform called GoingUP, that will use an on-chain track record of past interactions, formal and informal roles, connections, and awards to create a reputation score and a clear and on-chain proved overview of user capabilities. The proposal attached a Linktree consisting of their detailed plan on a website, pitch deck, and GitHub repository. The team has solid plan but crucial information are not provided on the proposal itself. The proposal gives potential risks that can have an effect on the project but they provide a plausible solution to mitigate those risks.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal provides a milestones and a roadmap with a timeframe for each months. However, the milestones on each month need to be written in more details. The proposal give a budget information but are not broken down enough. For example, they stated they will use 75K$ for the development of the product, how much of those money goest for developer remuneration? How long (e.g in hours) the developer work (in relation to their salary/hour)? How much gonna be spend on domain name, hosting fee or cloud server (if used)? The same goes to the 15K$ of User base building that need to be elaborates more. The proposal give a concise information on the background and experienc of each team member, they also provide a LinkedIn profile for every team member.
f6_assessments.q2: The measure used for tracking progress is defined but not in detail. Many items can be described in more detail, for example, how do you do a reality check on the roadmap? how often are the features gonna tested? are the testing just a unit test or include system integration testing? The indicators of success are also defined but not in a measurable manner, for example, how many users get on board to be considered successful? how many transactions/interactions on smart contract to be considered as success? etc.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal proposed the idea of creating an attendance system to solve the problem related to attendance identification and improve reliability. I think this is a good idea and this project will have the potential to accelerate the growth of the Cardano ecosystem.
The way the project works has been clearly and specifically stated by the proposers. The Solution section is described in great technical detail. This provides an overview of how the project affects the potential audience in particular and the Cardano ecosystem community in general.
The solution proposed by the proposal is also very suitable for the Key metrics of the challenge because it helps attract more projects to join the Cardano community. The project will provide services to enhance the user experience and thereby attract more talents and collaborators. The presentation of the proposers is also very detailed and clear in each section. This makes it very easy for viewers to visualize and evaluate the impact of the project. Overall, the project has met the impact requirements set forth by Challenge.
The proposal team also identified some difficulties when implementing the project. The risks have been predicted by the team and actively find solutions to minimize the impact of these difficulties on the project implementation.
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap that the proposal provides is quite sketchy. The roadmap should show the milestones of the plan and describe in detail what the project will deliver at the time of that roadmap or at that milestone. The proposal must show a reasonable plan not only for what tasks will be completed, but also clearly state the requirements for each work item when it is completed. The above information should be provided in the proposal so that the viewers can easily assess whether the proposed project's progress is in line with the blueprint.
The budget plan should also be more carefully prepared. The information is quite sketchy and incomplete. Please provide information about the items that the project needs to invest in, the number of personnel needed to implement the project, and the budget used to pay them. The information is not enough to assess whether this budget plan is consistent with the plan outlined in the proposal. Expenditure budgets should be broken down for each item and further detailed in bulleted form for easier tracking.
This project is being led by an experienced and knowledgeable management team. With the knowledge and skills that the management team has, the project is expected to be implemented on schedule and developed as promised.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team has not provided clear quantitative indicators. The community will rely on these indicators to evaluate the success of the project. Please imagine what specific numbers the project's success will yield. Please refer to the given key metrics and calculate the appropriate numbers for the project's results to provide a direction to evaluate the development progress of the project.
The criteria to evaluate the success of the project have been described very well by the proposers by building the image of the project when it is successful. The results of the project that promise to be achieved when successful are also mentioned in great detail.

f6_assessments.q0: This idea is aimed to address the issue of pseudonymous identity by increasing cooperation and improving accountability and trustworthiness in web3. The team intends to reward and enable users to build their reputation based on their achievements, interactions, and contributions by leveraging their on-chain track record of past interactions, formal and informal roles, connections, and awards to generate a reputation score and a clear and on-chain proven overview of your capabilities. Though I generally agree with the proposal's alignment with the challenge aim, no impact measures are supplied, preventing me from making an informed judgment. Aspects related to scalability problems that the project may face in the future are not addressed.
f6_assessments.q1: The team describes each team member's qualifications and expertise, all of whom have significant experience and a reputation within the Catalyst community. The implementation strategy is simple, and all of the actions that the team wants to follow are fully known. However, when it comes to the budget, while there is a detailed analysis of the components, the cost is not assigned to each item. As a result, an accurate assessment of the explanation for the required amount is impossible. Despite the lack of a section on the potential threats to the proposal's success, the team's experience gives me confidence that this initial phase will be successful. It would be preferable if the proposer allocated the budget breakdown through the project phases/months and provided additional specifics on how the funds would be used. For example, what will you need to produce a product that is engaging and suited for purpose while adding critical features?
f6_assessments.q2: The timeline supplied is extremely thorough, with basic goals indicated for each milestone; the KPIs provided are consistent with those on the Challenge Objectives. However, in order for the results and KPIs to be properly verified, some particular quantifiable measure targets should have been specified (e.g. the incremental number of wallets and users onboarded ). Because these activities are well publicized and attended by a large number of members of the community, I believe that while the project can be monitored and tracked to determine if it delivers the promised value, it would have been preferable to have those data (thus the 4)

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal for GoingUp concerns a reputation and collaboration tool for use in the Cardano ecosystem. The application wants it to become easier for people contributing in the web3 ecosystem to build their own reputation and get more recognition for their involvement. Upon inspection of the website and github repository this product has not been yet launched on the Ethereum blockchain and based off the roadmap is in the early stages of development. The proposers add a video showing some minimal functionality which is connecting and disconnecting an Ethereum wallet.  Due to the project not being live and only just started based on the roadmap and implementation provided this proposal is only somewhat aligned with the challenge brief that is looking to migrate existing DApps projects to the Cardano ecosystem. DApps & Integrations would have been a perfect challenge for this proposal as it is bringing a new solution to the ecosystem which is not yet launched.
f6_assessments.q1: The team have provided a Link Tree link that has a Github repository, website, demo video and Discord. They also provided LinkedIn profiles to showcase who is working on this project. It is clear the team has some of the skills needed to execute this project. What is less clear from the information provided is if they have the technical expertise around smart contracts and self sovereign identity. The proposal team also do not mention the usage or any considerations for self sovereign identity such as using Atala PRISM. It is unclear whether the team understands the implications of the governance models required and technical infrastructure that could support their application. It is hard to state with any confidence that the team understand the architecture required to implement what has been proposed and the trade offs they may be making for one decision over another. One recommendation will be that in a future proposal to clearly detail if they are using SSI and how they will be using it. To make a reputation based system this information must be clearly articulated to provide confidence that the team knows what will make a good implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: In the auditability section the team covers some high level targets for the project and how they will measure success. They mention 'We will measure our progress based on user adoption and interactions between users.'. It would have been useful to be more specific here on what interactions are important and why. It would have also been useful to compare with metrics from other competing solutions whether they are web 2.0 or web 3.0 solutions to help the assessor and community understand the bench marks in which the teams own KPIs are derived. If would have been more useful to understand the type of reputation or collaboration that was most important, or a grouping of examples that are most important, to create some KPIs against. With the current KPI suggestions it is difficult to truly have any confidence of whether this proposal will yield a good outcome against against the brief and also in general.

solution: GoingUP is a collaboration tool and an on-chain reputation scoring system for professionals in the crypto space.
experience: We have diverse skills in Business, Design, Development and web3. We have worked together on and off for about 1 year in the design and development of smart contracts for Crypto artists and launched several artists led NFT projects generating sales of about 50ETH in 3 months.
